Award.AwardTitle: NRT-DESE: Environment and Society: Data Science for the 21st century (DS421)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Global environmental change poses critical environmental and societal needs. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award prepares master's and doctoral students at the University of California - Berkeley with tools to advance frontiers at the intersection of social, natural, and data science. Trainees will develop skills in data visualization, informatics, software development, and science communication. Through an innovative team-based problem-solving course, trainees will collaborate with an external partner organization to tackle a challenge in global environmental change that includes a significant problem in data analysis and interpretation of impacts and solutions. A new generation of researchers and professionals interested in issues of environmental change will be trained in the emerging practices of open science, which will create fully reproducible and collaborative analyses that document the evidence for scientific conclusions and their implications for policy. This training program will advance progress on grand challenges of national and global importance.

The research theme of this program addresses grand challenges at the junction of open science and reproducible data analysis, responses of coupled human-natural systems to rapid environmental change, and development of evidence-based solutions. Trainees will research topics such as management of water resources, regional land use, and responses of agricultural systems to changes in economic and climate factors. Trainees will master the skills needed to evaluate how rapid environmental change impacts human and natural systems and to develop and evaluate solutions in public policy, resource management, and environmental design that will mitigate negative effects on human well-being. Trainees will learn to apply these skills examining the integrated dynamics of coupled human-natural systems from local to global scales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of Data Science for the 21st Century National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (DS421 NRT) were to bring together researchers in natural and social sciences with leaders in computer science and statistics to train a new generation of Master’s and Ph.D. students for careers in and out of academia at the intersection of the global environmental change and data science. Over 5 years, DS421 faculty and affiliates successfully trained 54 graduate students from 12 different disciplines in data visualization, scientific reproducibility, interdisciplinarity, and professional development skills early in their graduate careers.  

The two-year training program included 4 semester-long courses, two workshops, and a summer research project. The first colloquium introduced students to broadly interdisciplinary issues linked to climate change, such as natural disasters, energy and emissions, and environmental justice issues. Students then participated in an entry level coding workshop followed by an intensive data science course where they learned best practices for coding hygiene and reproducibility. The summer was spent in collaboration with a research lab outside of their home department. The second year began with a course on interdisciplinary research methods, during which students chose a final capstone project and external partner organization from the non-profit, governmental or industry sector. In the final semester, students worked in interdisciplinary teams to scope out and design projects, deliverables, and timelines to produce a data-driven visualization or analysis that was useful to the partner. Using skills from their science communication workshop, students presented final projects to peers, faculty, advisors, partners and affiliates at the end of the program. Some of these projects were later presented at scientific conferences.

The most successful elements of the program defined by student feedback and internal evaluation were the reproducible data science course, summer research internship, science communication workshop, and final projects course. These elements provided students the unique opportunity of sustained engagement to develop data science, collaborative research and communication skills. One of the most challenging aspects of the program was preparing students to build trust and engage with other disciplines. The program struggled to design elements that efficiently familiarized students with a common language to discuss interdisciplinary research questions. Students either felt like they were just skimming the surface of a topic or like they were drowning in information. Second, connecting the interdisciplinary work to students’ progress toward degree completion was essential. Advisors committed to the priorities of the program and in this case, interdisciplinary work, helped students to make this connection. Another challenge, unsurprisingly, was motivating students to engage in a two-year program with only one year of funding. The burden of funding and the influence of added responsibilities must be considered in the design of a program. Nevertheless, we continue to see the impact of the DS421 program evident in the alumni’s application of data science, research and communication skills in their research and careers. Future NRT programs can further tailor new opportunities for developing skills by designing elements that contribute to both program goals and academic goals. 

Across all of the program elements, DS421 has worked with 52 partner organizations. Students and staff have submitted 7 peer-reviewed papers and have 6 more in prep, 21 presentations at conferences, and 44 other publications, including data visualizations, magazine articles, radio broadcasts and blog posts. Through program elements, we have reached a total of 242 non-trainee graduate students, most of whom through our science communication workshop. The activities of the NRT on campus have galvanized many data science initiatives, including a new data science commons for graduate students, a new undergraduate degree, and progress towards a graduate data science certificate. The coordinator has handed over the science communication curriculum developed through DS421 to a science education organization, Science@Cal through Lawrence Berkeley Labs, to start a Berkeley Science Communication Fellows Program. This program will train the next generation of graduate science communication trainers and give them the opportunity to teach at least two workshops in the first year; training 12 new trainers and potentially reaching 320 people in the first year through online workshops.

DS421 program was able to recruit a slightly higher number of women (59%) than the average UC Berkeley graduate population (54%). The average proportion of under-represented minority students was 7% for African American students and 10% for Latinx students, which is higher than the UC proportions of 3-4% and 7-8%, respectively. We attended SACNAS every year and sent student representatives to talk to potential applicants about NRT programs. We participated in the UCB’s Diversity Day for visiting students. In the final year of recruiting, we worked with home departments to financially assist visiting student travel expenses if they applied to DS421. The NRT program was used as a recruitment tool for incoming URM graduate students though working actively with graduate student advisors, the graduate division, departmental diversity officers, and faculty.
